topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 2.0: DNSaaS Installation and Configuration

p.b: This document describes the installation process for HPE Helion OpenStack 2.0

body.p: Our managed DNS service, based on the OpenStack Designate project, is engineered to help you create, publish, and manage your DNS zones and records securely and efficiently to either a public or private DNS server network.
It is important to read through this page before starting your installation as it explains how to install and configure DNS as a service (DNSaaS) for HPE Helion OpenStack

Download the DNSaaS Cloud Image. Check against this value to ensure that you have the right file: 48a0ae226bc0f64396c4c959b1853b75 dnsaas-2.0.0-b.1_cloud-1.0.20151005T152959Z.qcow2
Credentials of the user+tenant where the service is to be deployed ("Target Credentials")

section.title: Creating the Prerequisite Credentials
section.p: Target credentials are the credentials of the user+tenant where the service is to be deployed. Target credentials include a tenant and a username. Service credentials can only be created after the Target credentials have been successfully created. These commands should be run from the HPE Helion OpenStack deployer.

ol.li: You will need to update your environment by sourcing the keystone.osrc file. $ source keystone.osrc

Create the DNSaaS project. Make a note of the ID field value.$ openstack project create dnsaas +-------------+----------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +-------------+----------------------------------+ | description | | | domain_id | default | | enabled | True | | id | a6c8339e816c4f4fb9118b31e2e101ad |
[ OUPUT TRIMMED]
Create a dnsaas user. $ openstack user create dnsaas --password password --email dnsaas@example.com --project dnsaas
Add roles to the dnsaas user. $ openstack role add --project dnsaas --user dnsaas _member_ $ openstack role add --project dnsaas --user dnsaas admin
You can view the roles with role list. $ openstack role list

section.title: DNSaaS User and Project Credentials
section.p: Prepare the credentials files for the DNSaaS user and project.
section.codeblock: $ cat <<EOF > dnsaas.osrc unset OS_DOMAIN_NAME export OS_IDENTITY_API_VERSION=3 export OS_AUTH_VERSION=3 export OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME=Default export OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME=Default export OS_ENDPOINT_TYPE=internalURL export OS_INTERFACE=internal export OS_CACERT=/etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt export OS_PROJECT_NAME=dnsaas export OS_USERNAME=dnsaas export OS_PASSWORD=password export OS_AUTH_URL=http://192.168.245.5:35357/v3 EOF

sectiondiv.b: Preparing to boot the Deployer VM
sectiondiv.p: You must publish the DNSaaS Cloud Image to the target project/tenant before proceeding to the next step.

ol.li: Update your environment. $ source dnsaas.osrc

Create image. Make a note of the value of the owner parameter and the DNS Cloud Image ID value.$ glance image-create --name "dnsaas-2.0.0-b.1_cloud-1.0.20151005T152959Z" \ --file "dnsaas-2.0.0-b.1_cloud-1.0.20151005T152959Z.qcow2" \ --is-public False \ --disk-format qcow2 \ --container-format bare

Identify the SVC network ID. Make a note of the SVC ID value.$ neutron net-show SVC +---------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Field | Value | +---------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | admin_state_up | True | | id | <service ID Value> |
[ OUTPUT TRIMMED ]
Upload the SSH keypair. $ nova keypair-add --pub-key dns_shared.pub dns-shared
You can view the keypair information with keypair-show. $ nova keypair-show dns-shared
Ensure the default security group is correctly configured. You will need the ID value from the "create the project" step.$ neutron security-group-list --tenant-id <value of the owner parameter>

Create security group rules. $ neutron security-group-rule-create \ --tenant-id <value of the owner parameter from OpenStack Project Create command> \ --protocol TCP \ --remote-ip-prefix 0.0.0.0/0 \ --port-range-min 22 \ --port-range-max 22 \ <default security group rule ID>
$ neutron security-group-rule-create \ --tenant-id <value of the project ID parameter from the OpenStack Project Create command> \ --protocol TCP \ --remote-ip-prefix 0.0.0.0/0 \ --port-range-min 79 \ --port-range-max 79 \ <default security group rule ID>
You can view the security groups with security_group_list $ neutron security-group-list --tenant-id <project ID>

sectiondiv.b: Booting the Deployer VM and Uploading the Deployer Tarball

ol.li: Boot the Deployer VM. $ nova boot --poll \ --nic net-id=<SVC ID Value> \ # SVC Network ID --image <DNS Cloud Image ID>\ # DNSaaS Cloud Image ID --key-name dns-shared \ # Keypair Name --flavor m1.small \ dnsaas-deployer
Display the dnsaas-deployer. Make a note of the SVC-NET IP Address.$ nova show dnsaas-deployer
Copy the dnsaas image. $ scp -i dns_shared dnsaas-2.0.0-b.1-20151005T183829Z.tgz stack@<SVC-NET IP Address>:~

sectiondiv.b: Login and Initialize the Deployer VM

ol.li:
Login to the deployer. $ ssh -i dns_shared stack@<SVC-NET IP Address> You will need to extract the dnsaas tar file and execute the dns-init.bash script. $ tar xf dnsaas-2.0.0-b.1-20151005T183829Z.tar $ cd dnsaas-2.0.0-b.1/ $ ./dnsaas-init.bash [ OUTPUT TRIMMED ]
+ ssh-keygen -q -t rsa -f id_rsa Enter passphrase (empty for no passphrase): Enter same passphrase again:
[ OUTPUT TRIMMED ]
# Do not continue with the installation steps that appear here # Ignore this next line. To continue installation copy your cloud layout to: /home/stack/helion/my_cloud/definition

section.title: Prepare the Deployment

sectiondiv.p: HPE Helion OpenStack DNSaaS has several example models that can be deployed. In the following example, the powerdns example deployment model is used.
sectiondiv.note: The cp command must be used exactly as shown - including the /* on the end of the example model path.
sectiondiv.codeblock: $ cd ~/helion $ cp -r examples/powerdns/* my_cloud/definition/ $ git add -A $ git commit -a -m "Add DNSaaS Example Model"

ol.li: You will need to change directories to the my_cloud/definition directory and run nano to configure your DNS and NTP servers. $ cd my_cloud/definition/ $ nano cloudConfig.yml
Run the ansible-playbook on the HPE Helion OpenStack deployer.cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts platform-pass-through.yml -e pass_through_key=""

Copy the contents of the pass-through.yml file as follows:
Copy from: <HOS deployer>:~/platform-pass-through.yml
Copy to: <DNSaaS deployer> ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/pass-through/hos.yml

Create SSL Certificates
If you want to install a self-signed certificate that meets the needs of HPE Helion OpenStack and HPE Helion Development Platform, follow these steps.
You will need a real or fictional domain name e.g. "your.domain.com" and it must match across the next 3 steps.
Create a Certificate Signing Request (CSR) with a defined subject. cd ~ openssl req -nodes -days 365 -newkey rsa:2048 -keyout my-public-cert.key -out my-public-cert.csr -text \ -subj '/C=US/O=Helion Test Certificate/CN=your.domain.com/emailAddress=test@example.org/'
Create a file containing v3 extensions Ensure that the DNS entry matches any CN entry above and provide your IP address. The IP address is what is used by HPE Helion Development Platform and the DNS is used by HPE Helion OpenStack. The IP address must be the same in DNS: and IP: $ cat > v3_ext.cnf << EOF [ v3_req ] subjectAltName=DNS:your.domain.com, DNS:10.0.0.1, IP:10.0.0.1 EOF
Self-sign your certificate. $ openssl x509 -extfile v3_ext.cnf -extensions v3_req -in my-public-cert.csr -signkey my-public-cert.key -req -out my-public-cert.crt -text
Installing the certificate. If you are using a FQDN - Create or obtain a certificate to match the domain name you are going to use.
Join the private and public keys into "my-cert-file" at the required location. $ cat my-public-cert.key my-public-cert.crt > ~/helion/my_cloud/config/tls/certs/my-public-cert
Edit network_groups.yml to set the values for "external-name" and "cert-file" under "load-balancers". $ nano ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/pass-through$network_groups.yml

Add your changes to Git. $ cd ~/helion $ git commit -a -m "Configured Deployment Model" $ git status Make sure that there are no other files which are not committed to the Git repository. If there are, begin troubleshooting.

sectiondiv.p: Copy the ~/dnsaas.osrc file from the HPE Helion OpenStack deployer. At the end of each playbook, ensure both "unreachable" and "failed" are zero.

sectiondiv.note: When asked for a encryption key, simply leave the value blank, pressing enter 4 times to proceed.

sectiondiv.p: Once this is complete, all in-cloud infrastructure (VMs, Networks, Routers, Floating IPs etc) will have been created.
sectiondiv.note: This step takes approximately 15 minutes to run.
sectiondiv.codeblock:
$ cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible
# Choose between single or multiple control plane. You only need to execute one or the other, do not run both.
# a) Multiple control plane nodes $ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost hlm-boot-infra.yml
# b) Single control plane $ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost hlm-boot-infra.yml -e neutron_router_ha=False

sectiondiv.note: Unlike all the previous ansible play's, the inventory file supplied to this play is hosts/verb_hosts and not hosts/localhost.
This step take approximately 15 to 20 minutes to complete.
